subject: The demise of cursive handwriting
msgSnippet: This may not be a useful topic for the Quikscript forum -- but if anyone uses Quikscript to communicate with others [see the new poll], it seems germane.
messageBody:
This may not be a useful topic for the Quikscript forum -- but if
anyone uses Quikscript to communicate with others" [see the new
poll], it seems germane. Earlier this month, a staff writer in the
Raleigh NC newspaper wrote a story that cursive handwriting (as a
subject taught to school children) seems to be fading away. Students
use keyboards to do much of their writing. Often, homework
assignments are required to be typed, not written; and assignments
may be turned in using email. (Census surveys show that 70 percent of
homes now have computers.) The teaching of handwriting has become
inconsistent. Students eventually discover that they don't *need to
use* cursive writing for much of anything except checkwriting &
signing legal documents. A local middle school teacher stopped
writing notes in cursive on her whiteboard 3 years ago because every
class she teaches has students who don't know how to read it.
(Copyrighted article on newsobserver.com; I can send a link to it
later if someone asks for it.)

Do you think Quikscript would have anything helpful to offer for this
problem?
